Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Transcript-Based Differential Expression Analysis for Population Data Without Predefined Conditions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
With the emergence of precision medicine, there is increased demand for more sensitive molecular biomarkers. A fundamental computational step in the discovery of molecular biomarkers is to identify genes that are expressed differently across different samples. This project investigates new algorithmic approaches for performing differential expression analysis at the transcript level for samples without predefined biological conditions. Such an analysis is critical to both clinical and biological studies on population (or cohort) data. For example, it can be used to discover molecular biomarkers to classify cancer samples into subtypes so that better diagnosis and therapy methods can be developed for each subtype. It can also be used to characterize individual cells involved in different biological processes. Efficient software tools can be built based on the new analysis approaches proposed in this project which can help biologists to discover more sensitive biomarkers than the existing methods.

Specifically, this project studies three approaches for differential transcript expression analysis on population data. The first two approaches treat either the exons or full transcripts of a gene as the basic expression elements and then apply a gene-level differential expression analysis method on these expression elements. The third approach is a hybrid of the first two. It uses a splice graph to represent the transcripts of a gene and a new modular decomposition algorithm to partition the graph into small components that correspond to independent alternative splicing events. Moreover, a robust clustering algorithm is employed to deal with an arbitrary number of conditions in the input population. The software implementations of the three approaches are calibrated and tested extensively on both simulated and real sequence data to establish their practical utility to the public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this NSF project, the PI and his graduate students and collaborators conducted research on several fundamental problems concerning alternative splicing and its impact in differential expression analysis and functional genomics. Their special interest is how new techniques developed in the deep learning field could improve the inference of alternative polydenylation sites and isoform (or mRNA transcript) functions.

Their work on the prediction of alternative polyadenylation sites of isoforms from RNA-Seq expression profiles, genomic sequences and RNA secondary structures will likely result in more accurate annotations of isoforms in the transcriptomics practice since most existing transcriptome assembly tools including Cufflinks and StringTie are unable to estimate the external boundaries of isoforms accurately. Their work on the inference of isoform functions from gene functions based on RNA-seq data and genomic sequence features may provide insight on how different isoforms of the same gene may take on different funtional roles in a cell. This will further establish the importance of transcript-based differential expression analysis and inspire more interest in isoform-based functional analysis. The work has also demonstrated interesting combinations of different techniques from the machine learning community, such as multiple instance learning combined with transfer learning and deep neural networks combined with conditional random fields, etc. Their study on tissue-specific regulatory networks (CSNets) could provide a useful resouce for the regulatory genomics community. The project has resulted in multiple publications in leading bioinformatics and genomics journals such as Bioinformatics, Genome Biology, Nucleic Acids Research, Cell Systems, and BMC Genomics, and top bioinformatics conferences including RECOMB and ISMB, as well as many software tools that have been made available to the public for free.

The project has also provided training opportunies for four Ph.D students and two MSc students in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering at UC Riverside. Except for one student, the students had no prior experience in genomics or bioinformatics. Through the research work, they learned how to understand and process real biological (sequencing) data, how to interact with biologists and understand their needs, and how to make their work/tools more relevant to biological practice. The research topics and results generated from the project have also been used to enhance classroom teaching at both the graduate and undergraduate levels.
